columns.text: In this exercise, we are going to learn about debt valuation and asset variance using Black Scholes Model.

To start with, let us define  Black Scholes Model. 

**Black Scholes Model** is a mathematical equation that involves probabilities to compute the price of an option. 

The equation of the Black Scholes Model is illustrated as follows: 

$$\textbf{C}=\text{S}\times\text{N}_{\text{(d1})}-\text{X}\times\text{e}^{\text{-rt}}\times\text{N}_{\text{(d2)}}$$

Where: 

- C- Call Option
- S- Stock Price
- X - Exercise Price
- r - rate
- t - time
- N(d1) - Probability if z is less than or equal to d1
- N(d2) - Probability if z is less than or equal to d2

Whereas d1 is solved as follows: 

$$\textbf{d}_{1}=\frac{\left[\text{ln}\frac{\text{S}}{\text{X}}\right]+\left(\text{r}+\frac{σ^2}{2}\right)\times\text{t}}{\left(σ\times\sqrt{\text{t}}\right)}$$

And d2's equation is illustrated below: 

$$\textbf{d}_{2}=\text{d}_{1}-σ\times\sqrt{\text{t}}$$

Where: 

- σ - Standard deviation
- ln - natural logarithm

Here are the parameters to solve the problem : 


|Given | | 
|--|--| 
|Market value of asset (S) |$62,000| 
| Face value of debt (X) |$65,000 | 
|Risk-free rate (r) | 7% | 
|Time (t) |5 years | 
|Standard deviation(σ) | 34% per year| 
| e| 2.71828|

## Requirement A

We are asked to solve the value of a risk-free bond with the same face value and maturity as the current bond.

Next, let us solve the natural logarithm of the quotient of the value of assets and the face value of debt. 

We are going to use excel to solve the natural logarithm. The formula should look as follows: 


 !['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/2d6171c4-e3a6-4dbe-84f5-65dfd84fcd07-1661861166255241.png)

Therefore ln(S/X) is -0.0473.

Now, we solve the value of d2 using the equation in Step 3: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{d}_{2}&=0.7782-0.34\times\sqrt{5}\\[15pt]
&=0.7782-0.34\times2.2361\\[15pt]
&=0.7782-0.7603\\[15pt]
&=0.0179
\end{aligned}$$

Thus, the value of d2 is 0.0179.

Now, here are the values of N(d1) and N(d2) using the cumulative normal distribution table: 


|Normal distribution | | 
|--|--| 
|Nd1 |0.7823 | 
|Nd2 |0.5080 |

Using the equation in Step 2, the value of the call option is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{C}&=\$62,000\times0.7823-\$65,000\times2.71828^{-(0.07)(5)}\times0.5080\\[15pt]
&=\$62,000\times0.7823-\$65,000\times2.71828^{-(0.35)}\times0.5080\\[15pt]
&=\$62,000\times0.7823-\$65,000\times0.7047\times0.5080\\[15pt]
&=\$62,000\times0.7823-\$65,000\times0.358\\[15pt]
&=\$48,503-\$23,270\\[15pt]
&=\boxed{\$25,233}
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the value of the risk-free bond is $25,233.

## Requirement B

We are asked to solve the value of a put option. 

The equation of the put option is illustrated below: 

 

$$\textbf{P}=\text{X}\times\text{e}^{-\text{rt}}+\text{C}-\text{S}$$

Where : 

- P - Put option
- X - Exercise price
- r - risk-free rate
- t - time
- C- Call option
- S - Stock price

## Requirement C 

We are required to solve the value of the firm's debt and the cost of debt.

The value of the firm's debt is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Debt}&=\text{Call Option}-\text{Put Option}\\[15pt]
&=\$25,233-\$9,039\\[15pt]
&=\$16,194
\end{aligned}$$

The put option is deducted from the call option to determine the value of the debt. 

Thus, the value of the firm's debt is $16,194.

The cost of debt is solved as follows. 

Let *r* be the cost of debt: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Value of debt}&=\text{Face value}\times\text{e}^{-\text{rt}}\\[15pt]
\$16,194&=\$65,000\times2.71828^{-\text{(r)}(5)}\\[15pt]
2.71828^{-\text{(r)}(5)}&=\frac{\$16,194}{\$65,000}\\[20pt]
2.71828^{-\text{(5r)}}&=0.2491\\[15pt]
\textbf{r}&=\boxed{0.2780\space\text{or}\space27.80\%}
\end{aligned}$$

Thus, the cost of debt is 27.80%.

## Requirement D

We are asked to solve the value of debt and cost of debt if the standard deviation increases to 43%.

Now, we solve the value of d2 using the equation in Step 3: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{d}_{2}&=0.7956-0.43\times\sqrt{5}\\[15pt]
&=0.7956-0.43\times2.2361\\[15pt]
&=0.7956-0.9615\\[15pt]
&=-0.1659
\end{aligned}$$

Thus, the value of d2 is -0.1659.

Using the equation in Step 2, the value of the call option is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{C}&=\$62,000\times0.7881-\$65,000\times2.71828^{-(0.07)(5)}\times0.4325\\[15pt]
&=\$62,000\times0.7881-\$65,000\times2.71828^{-(0.35)}\times0.4325\\[15pt]
&=\$62,000\times0.7881-\$65,000\times0.7047\times0.4325\\[15pt]
&=\$62,000\times0.7881-\$65,000\times0.3048\\[15pt]
&=\$48,862-\$19,812\\[15pt]
&=\$29,050
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the value of the risk-free bond is $29,050.

Using the equation in Step 11, the price of the put option is solved as follows: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{P}&=\$65,000\times2.71828^{-(0.07)(5)}+\$29,050-\$62,000\\[15pt]
&=\$65,000\times0.7047+\$29,050-\$62,000\\[15pt]
&=\$45,806+\$29,050-\$62,000\\[15pt]
&=\$12,856
\end{aligned}$$

Hence, the value of the put option is $12,856.

The value of the firm's debt is solved below: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Debt}&=\text{Call Option}-\text{Put Option}\\[15pt]
&=\$29,050-\$12,856\\[15pt]
&=\$16,194
\end{aligned}$$

The put option is deducted from the call option to determine the value of the debt. 

Thus, the value of the firm's debt is $16,194.

The cost of debt is solved as follows. 

Let *r* be the cost of debt: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Value of debt}&=\text{Face value}\times\text{e}^{-\text{rt}}\\[15pt]
\$16,194&=\$65,000\times2.71828^{-\text{(r)}(5)}\\[15pt]
2.71828^{-\text{(r)}(5)}&=\frac{\$16,194}{\$65,000}\\[20pt]
2.71828^{-\text{(5r)}}&=0.2491\\[15pt]
\textbf{r}&=\boxed{0.2780\space\text{or}\space27.80\%}
\end{aligned}$$

Thus, the cost of debt is 27.80%.
